qas.question: What was the first book on environmental ethics by an individual author?

answers.text: Is It Too Late? A Theology of Ecology

qas.question: On which economics book did Cobb collaborate with Herman Daly?

answers.text: For the Common Good: Redirecting the Economy toward Community, the Environment, and a Sustainable Future

qas.question: What award did Cobb and Daly receive for the book?

answers.text: Grawemeyer Award for Ideas Improving World Order

qas.question: What other economics book did Cobb go on to author?

answers.text: Sustaining the Common Good: A Christian Perspective on the Global Economy

qas.question: What was the goal of Cobb's second book on economics?

answers.text: to challenge "economists' zealous faith in the great god of growth."

plausible_answers.text: Is It Too Late? A Theology of Ecology

qas.question: What was the last book on environmental ethics by an individual author?

plausible_answers.text: the Common Good: A Christian Perspective on the Global Economy

qas.question: On which economics book did Cobb kick out Herman Daly?

plausible_answers.text: Grawemeyer Award for Ideas Improving World Order

qas.question: What award did Cobb and Daly lose for the book?

plausible_answers.text: Sustaining the Common Good: A Christian Perspective on the Global Economy

qas.question: What other science book did Cobb go on to author?

context: This work has been pioneered by John B. Cobb, Jr., whose book <a0_0><b5_0>Is It Too Late? A Theology of Ecology<b5_0/><a0_0/> (1971) was the first single-authored book in environmental ethics. Cobb also co-authored a book with economist Herman Daly entitled <a1_0>For the Common Good: Redirecting the Economy toward Community, the Environment, and a Sustainable Future<a1_0/> (1989), which applied Whitehead's thought to economics, and received the <a2_0><b7_0>Grawemeyer Award for Ideas Improving World Order<b7_0/><a2_0/>. Cobb followed this with a second book, <a3_0><b8_0>Sustaining <b6_0>the Common Good: A Christian Perspective on the Global Economy<b8_0/><b6_0/><a3_0/> (1994), which aimed <a4_0>to challenge "economists' zealous faith in the great god of growth."
